thread.title: 5 keys for the Patriots against the Jets - Patriots
thread.title_full: 5 keys for the Patriots against the Jets - Patriots

author: boston.com
title: 5 keys for the Patriots against the Jets - Patriots
text:
COMMENTARY
When Tom Brady heads to the line of scrimmage for his first snap of the game on Sunday, he’ll be facing the best defense he’s seen all year. When former Patriots and current Jets cornerback Darrelle Revis lines up across from him, he’ll be facing the best offense he has seen all year.
And so the Jets-Patriots matchup will be a proving ground for both groups, because, frankly neither has been greatly tested by their opponents so far. The Patriots are scoring the league’s most points per game, and the Jets have allowed the fewest.
 Here are the keys to a Patriots victory over the Jets.
1. Don’t throw at Darrelle Revis
Unless it’s Rob Gronkowski.
Because of his size, Gronk is one of the only players in the league who may have an advantage against Revis. However, Revis likely won’t be tasked with covering Gronk—at least not on every play—and so Brady would be wise to throw away from the shutdown corner.
For whatever reason, quarterbacks haven’t gotten the memo about Revis this season. And he’s caught three interceptions.
Redskins quarterback Kirk Cousins seemed to forget where Revis was on the field, and threw the ball to a receiver in the flat. Pick.
Colts quarterback Andrew Luck threw downfield to rookie Phillip Dorsett covered by Revis. Pick.
Dolphins quarterback Ryan Tannehill targeted Revis in the redzone (WHY!?). Pick.
Revis’s secondary is so good, Ryan Fitzpatrick has led three of the Jets’ five games in passing. Yes, the Ryan Fitzpatrick.
2. Get LeGarrette Blount and Dion Lewis involved early and often
The Jets defense has allowed the fewest yards per game, second-fewest passing yards per game, and second-fewest rushing yards per game.
There isn’t one particular way to beat them.
The first place to start, however, is with the Patriots’ running backs. New England can start by getting Lewis in space as a receiving threat — there isn’t a linebacker on the Jets (and perhaps in the NFL) that can cover him. Then they can counter with Blount, whose quick feet and tree-trunk legs should challenge the tackling ability of the Jets’ elite group of linebackers.
3. Figure out the left tackle situation
Against the Colts, Marcus Cannon was in for a handful of snaps before leaving the game with an injury, at which point Sebastian Vollmer moved to left tackle and Cameron Fleming moved to right. It’s likely the Patriots will want to Cannon back at left tackle, if he’s healthy .
But there may not be a worse game for Cannon to get his sea legs at left tackle. The Jets’ defensive front is one of the best in the league. Defensive end Sheldon Richardson said the Jets are “ licking their chops. ”
With the way the Patriots offensive line has looked through five games, he’s got good reason to be excited.
4. Pressure and contain Ryan Fitzpatrick
Chris Ivory has been the most important offensive player for the Jets, and the Patriots will struggle mightily to stop him.
But the Patriots have an easier target.
Fitzpatrick has thrown an interception in each of the Jets games this year. He follows the line of Jets quarterbacks where there’s little question as to whether he’ll turn the ball over. Instead, it’s a matter of when he’ll do it. To encourage Fitzpatrick to turn the ball over, Chandler Jones and Jamie Collins will need to get after Fitzpatrick, while containing him pocket to prevent him from scrambling. In the last two games, Fitzpatrick has rushed for 65 yards and a touchdown.
The more he’s throwing the ball, the better off the Patriots are.
5. Get the ball in Gronk’s hands
And good things happen.
For the first three games, Gronk caught four touchdowns and was averaging over 100 yards per game. In the last two games, he’s caught one touchdown and averaged 58.5 yards. He went the first half against the Colts without a catch.
Even when Gronk isn’t racking up yards, he’s invaluable.
When opponents dedicate quality and quantity personnel to covering Gronk, it’s easier for Brady to go elsewhere (to Julian Edelman, Danny Amendola, or even Scott Chandler). But the Jets are deep enough in the secondary, and Brady may not have that luxury. They Patriots will need him to create separation and get yards after the catch.
Playing both sides: These guys have worn Patriots and Jets colors
Previous -- of -- Next Ty Law spent 10 seasons with New England after getting drafted in the first round of the 1995 draft and won three Super Bowls. The five-time Pro Bowler spent two seasons with the Jets in 2005 and 2008. During his 15-year career, he had 707 tackles and 53 interceptions. Kathy Willens/AP Previous -- of -- Next Darrelle Revis spent one season in New England in 2014, and came away with a Super Bowl win. After getting drafted in the first round of the 2007 NFL Draft, Revis spent six seasons with the Jets, and rejoined them for the 2015 season. So far in his career with the Jets, he has 249 tackles and 22 interceptions. Steven Flynn/USA Today Previous -- of -- Next Vinny Testaverde spent seven years with the Jets from 1998 to 2003 and another year in 2005, and passed for 1,854 yards and 77 touchdowns. He spent one season backing up Tom Brady in New England, where he attempted only three passes in 2006. Testeverde was the first-overall pick in the 1987 NFL Draft and was a two-time Pro Bowler. Jim Davis/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Danny Woodhead went undrafted in the 2008 NFL Draft, but was signed by the Jets in the days following. He was released by the Jets in 2010 and signed by New England, where he had 2,181 yards and 14 touchdowns during his time with the Patriots. Patrick Smith/Getty Images Previous -- of -- Next Kenbrell Thompkins was signed by the Patriots as an undrafted free agent in 2013. He spent the 2013 season and some of the 2014 season with New England. With the Pats, he had 519 yards and four touchdowns. He signed with the Jets in 2015. Jared Wickerham/Getty Images Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next The Patriots selected Stevan Ridley in the third round of the 2015 NFL Draft. A two-time AFC champion with the Patriots, Ridley signed with the New York Jets in the 2011 offseason. Jim Davis/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Tim Tebow joined the Patriots for training camp in 2013 after spending the 2012 season with the New York Jets. He didn't make the Patriots roster, but did play in 12 games for the Jets, was 6 of 8 passing, and rushed the ball 32 times for 102 yards. Jim Davis/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Bryan Cox played for the Jets for three seasons from 1998 to 2000. The original Miami Dolphin spent one season with the Patriots in 2001, and helped win Super Bowl XXXVI. Barry Chin/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next As head coach of the Seattle Seahawks, Pete Carroll lost in the Super Bowl to his former team, the New England Patriots. He was the franchise's head coach from 1997 to 1999. He also spent four seasons with the Jets, and served as their head coach for the 1994 season. Winslow Townson/AP Previous -- of -- Next Hank Poteat spent three seasons with the Patriots from 2004 to 2006. The Super Bowl champ then joined the Jets from 2006 to 2008. He finished his NFL career with 197 tackles, four interceptions, and three sacks. Stephan Savoia/AP Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Bill Parcells was the Patriots head coach from 1993 to 1996. He took the Patriots Super Bowl XXXI, but lost to the Green Bay Packers, 35–21. He left the next season to serve as the Jets head coach from 1997 to 1999. R. Emmett Sullivan/AP Previous -- of -- Next Roman Phifer spent four seasons in New England and two in New York during his 15-year career. The linebacker had 68 tackles, 8.5 sacks, and two interceptions for the Jets. He had 203 tackles, two interceptions and four sacks for the Patriots. Matthew J. Lee/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next In 1999, the Jets promoted Bill Belichick to be their head coach after spending two seasons as an assistan. Less than 24 hours later, however, the Patriots exchanged a first round pick with the Jets to hire Belichick as their head coach, With the Patriots, has won four Super Bowls. John Greilick/AP Previous -- of -- Next Curtis Martin played exclusively with the Jets and Patriots during his 11-year career. The Hall of Famer racked up 14,101 rushing yards, 90 rushing touchdowns, 3,329 receiving yards, and 10 receiving touchdowns. He was drafted by the Patriots in the third round and spent three seasons in New England before leaving for New York. Jim Davis/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Fullback Keith Byars spent 10 games in 1996 and all of the 1997 season with the Patriots. He then left for the Jets in 1998, and retired at the end of that season. During his 14-year career, the Pro Bowler had 31 receiving touchdowns, 23 rushing touchdowns, and six passing touchdowns. Mike Segar/Reuters Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Patriots tight end Jermaine Wiggins went undrafted but signed with the Jets in 1999. He split time in 2000 with the Patriots and Jets during his rookie season. He then spent the 2001 season with the Patriots, and won Super Bowl XXXVI. Matthew J. Lee/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Zach Sudfeld was signed by the Patriots as an undrafted free agent after the 2013 NFL Draft. He was released after playing three games with the team, and signed with the Jets. During the 2014 season, he played 16 games, started three, and caught five receptions for 85 yards. Bill Kostroun/AP Previous -- of -- Next Cornerback Otis Smith scored eight touchdowns during his 14-year career. He spent five seasons with the Jets, and three seasons with the New England Patriots, where he won Super Bowl XXXVI. He finished his career with 442 tackles, 29 interceptions, and five forced fumbles. Kathy Willens/AP Previous -- of -- Next Special teams stalwart Larry Izzo never left the AFC East during his 13-year career. The undrafted free agent linebacker and special teams player signed with the Dolphins in 1996. He joined the Patriots in 2001, won three Super Bowls, then joined the Jets in 2009. He finished his career with 132 tackles. Davis, Jim Globe Staff Previous -- of -- Next Damien Woody was drafted in the first round by the Patriots in the 1999 NFL Draft, where he played for five years and missed only two games. He signed with the Jets in 2008 where he played right tackle through the 2010 season. Matt Sullivan/Reuters Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Bobby Hamilton went undrafted in 1994, and eventually signed with the Jets and played with New York through the 1999 season. He signed with the Patriots in 2000, where he amassed 137 tackles in four seasons, winning a pair of Super Bowls. Al Bello/Getty Images Previous -- of -- Next Quarterback Ray Lucas spent the 1996 season with the Patriots after going undrafted. He joined the Jets in 1997 and played in New York for four seasons. He finished his career with 18 touchdowns, 17 interceptions, and 3,029 yards. Jim Davis/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next Defensive end Anthony Pleasant spent the 1998 and 1999 seasons with the Jets, where he had 75 tackles and eight sacks. He played with New England from 2001 to 2003, where he won two Super Bowls, had 10 sacks, and recorded 52 tackes. Jim Davis/The Boston Globe Previous -- of -- Next The Jets drafted Dedric Ward in the third round of the 1997 NFL Draft. In his four seasons in New York, he had 1,815 receiving yards and 11 touchdowns. The Super Bowl champion spent two seasons with the Dolphins but played with the Patriots for the 2003 season. Michael Robinson-Chavez/The Boston Globe
